Octochrome, the Ununlockable Rare
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher Advance 2 Archive (GameBoy Advance): The Shrine (Passwords and Unlocking): Octochrome, the Ununlockable Rare
By GoldenBoy on Friday, October 10, 2003 - 08:03 pm:

Since people seem to have trouble parsing this info out of
the thread we already have devoted to the topic, here is the
definitve staus report on the final monster in MRA2 that we
have yet to successfully unlock.

#240 Octochrome (Sp-U)

Octochrome is an attack rare (see other threads for what
that means). If you raise an Octopee you have a chance to
get attacked by Gorkin. When you beat him, you get the
password MAC_OCT when you use it at the Shrine, it gives
you a special Ducken named Brinjalon. thanks to
Kurasu for uncovering this This is a monster that normally
has no unlocking requirements. The conclusion is that the
password is defective, and points to the wrong memory
register.

Lisa has asked Brian at Tecmo about it, and he has passed
the request on to Japan. Don't ask whether she's heard
back yet, I seriously doubt Lisa will forget to mention it if
she does hear.

People have made several alternate suggestions without
verifying them on their own. I'm not alone among MRM
mods in not wanting to hear about them any more. If you
have an idea, try it. If it doesn't work then post it and tell us
that, but don't create work for other people, that's not the
way MRM works.

The only remaining possibility as I see it is this: There may
be more than one password for the attack rares. It is
possible but unlikely that someone who has gotten the
Gorkin Event could use a password to successfully generate
an Octochrome. However, the possibility is slim to none. No
other attack rares have a second password. This route of
research would be simple, boring, password crunching.


*Off Topic*
On a personal note, I am sad that I have gotten so close to
earning a full collection of 511 out of 512 monsters, but
won't be able to finish seemingly. However I am more than
satisfied with the work I have done one research for this
game, and am not particularly gung-ho about doing work
on one last monster. I deliberately eased off when we got
the majority of monsters, since I wanted to leave something
for other people to do.

This kinda sounds like some odd goodbye post huh? It's
not I assure you. I've got cleanup in this section when I get
around to it, and there is still plenty of things to write up
about MRA2. I'd like to see a nice comprehensive post on
exploration, and I swear I'll finish updating those maps
someday.

By marhawkman on Wednesday, March 10, 2004 - 06:07 pm:

Maybe the defect is in the Password interpreter.

I personally suspect that the "special" passwords you get in the game don't enter into the Monster Generator the same way the others do.

I think that instead the game checks to see if it's a pre-formed password and then uses the data for the preformed monster instead of the normal generation method.

By marhawkman on Wednesday, March 10, 2004 - 06:17 pm:

Err... forgot the last thing. I think that they didn't put that password in the "special" list. since I've never done the OctoChrome event but I got a Brinjalon with "MAC_OCT" anyways. Also I have done the event that gives you the "Sun_Bath" Password.

So apparently the password is defective. :p It should be possible to get a different password for it though. But you'll have to use the event to be able to regenerate.

By marhawkman on Monday, March 15, 2004 - 01:39 pm:

Okay I did some more research into the Pre-Set passwords. It appears that the game has a special memory area where it stores the monster data for them. I.E. they don't go into the generator like the other ones. The thing I noticed recently was that it stores ALL the data. Stats, traits, etc.. I think the error with this one is that the stored data has the wrong Family value which, in this case, results in a monster in the ducken family. So in conclusion, Mac_Oct IS a pre-set password, as far as monster generation is concerned, but the programmers screwed up and accidentally programmed in Brinjallon instead of OctoChrome.

By Lisa Shock on Monday, March 15, 2004 - 10:49 pm:
